article.paragraph: TheBeerLambert law, also known asBeer's law, theLambertBeer law, or theBeerLambertBouguer lawrelates theAbsorption (electromagnetic radiation)attenuationoflightto the properties of the material through which the light is traveling. The law is commonly applied tochemical analysismeasurements and used in understanding attenuation inphysical optics, forphotons,neutronsor rarefied gases. Inmathematical physics, this law arises as a solution of theBhatnagar-Gross-KrookBGK equation.
article.heading: History
article.paragraph: The law was discovered byPierre Bouguerbefore 1729.Pierre Bouguer,''Essai d'optique sur la gradation de la lumire''(Paris, France: Claude Jombert, 1729) pp. 1622.It is often attributed toJohann Heinrich Lambert, who cited Bouguer'sEssai d'optique sur la gradation de la lumire(Claude Jombert, Paris, 1729)and even quoted from itin hisPhotometriain 1760.J.H. Lambert,''Photometria sive de mensura et gradibus luminis, colorum et umbrae''[Photometry, or, On the measure and gradations of light, colors, and shade] (Augsburg ("Augusta Vindelicorum"), Germany: Eberhardt Klett, 1760). See especiallyp. 391.Lambert's law stated that absorbance of a material sample is directly proportional to its thickness (path length). Much later,August Beerdiscovered another attenuation relation in 1852. Beer's law stated that absorbance is proportional to the concentrations of the attenuating species in the material sample in 1852.Beer (1852)"Bestimmung der Absorption des rothen Lichts in farbigen Flssigkeiten"(Determination of the absorption of red light in colored liquids),Annalen der Physik und Chemie, vol. 86, pp. 7888.The modern derivation of the BeerLambert law combines the two laws and correlates the absorbance to both the concentrations of the attenuating species as well as the thickness of the material sample.cite bookJ. The law tends to break down at very high concentrations, especially if the material is highlyscattering. If the radiation is especially intense,nonlinear opticsnonlinear opticalprocesses can also cause variances. The main reason, however, is the following. At high concentrations, the molecules are closer to each other and begin to interact with each other. This interaction will change several properties of the molecule, and thus will change the attenuation.

article.heading: Validity
article.paragraph: Under certain conditions BeerLambert law fails to maintain a linear relationship between attenuation and concentration ofanalyte.Mehta A.Limitations and Deviations of BeerLambert LawThese deviations are classified into three categories:

list.listitem: Realfundamental deviations due to the limitations of the law itself.
Chemicaldeviations observed due to specific chemical species of the sample which is being analyzed.
Instrumentdeviations which occur due to how the attenuation measurements are made.

article.paragraph: There are at least six conditions that need to be fulfilled in order for BeerLambert law to be valid. These are:

list.listitem: The attenuators must act independently of each other.
The attenuating medium must be homogeneous in the interaction volume.
The attenuating medium must not scatter the radiationnoturbidityunless this is accounted for as inDifferential optical absorption spectroscopyDOAS.
The incident radiation must consist of parallel rays, each traversing the same length in the absorbing medium.

The incident radiation should preferably bemonochromatic, or have at least a width that is narrower than that of the attenuating transition. Otherwise a spectrometer as detector for the power is needed instead of a photodiode which has not a selective wavelength dependence.

The incident flux must not influence the atoms or molecules; it should only act as a non-invasive probe of the species under study. In particular, this implies that the light should not cause optical saturation or optical pumping, since such effects will deplete the lower level and possibly give rise to stimulated emission.

article.paragraph: If any of these conditions are not fulfilled, there will be deviations from BeerLambert law.
article.heading: Chemical analysis by spectrophotometry
article.paragraph: BeerLambert law can be applied to the analysis of a mixture byspectrophotometry, without the need for extensive pre-processing of the sample. The law is used widely ininfra-red spectroscopyandnear-infrared spectroscopyfor analysis ofpolymer degradationandoxidation(also in biological tissue). Thecarbonyl groupattenuation at about 6 micrometres can be detected quite easily, and degree of oxidation of thepolymercalculated.
